text.title: Raise a Child to Respect Religion

text:
Raise a Child to Respect ReligionReligion and faith are both important foundations in the upbringing of many children. Teaching children to respect their own faith, as well as the beliefs of others can help them live in harmony. This article will show practical ways to do so.
Steps
Stay neutral. If you place one religion on a pedestal or give it higher importance than another one, your child will have a hard time respecting religion and treating all beliefs as equal. Keep your explanations neutral and fact-based, and save your personal beliefs for a later discussion, if your child initiates it.
Try not to belittle any religion or compare one to another. Let them know that all religions teach people to be good to one another.
Explain how people adopt their religion. It is crucial for the parent to know about his/her own religion first and how they adopted it because until we know this, we can't pass knowledge on to our children.Â Many parents make the mistake of pushing faith on kids without looking at the consequences of prohibiting choice.
Teach kids about faith. It can help them make a wise and informed choice regarding their own worship. You can teach kids about:
The most prominent figure of that religion
The place people of that religion worship
The holy book, and what it means to different people
Traditions and religious customs.
Teach about all religions. While many people place a focus on the religion they want their child to be or the religion that's most common where they live, it doesn't give your child a well-rounded view of religion. Talk about all major religions, not just your faith or the most common ones in your area, so they get to learn about all religions and make a decision of their own.
If you don't know enough about a certain religion to explain it to your child, research it with them. You could visit the library and pick out books to read together, or look it up online together.
Don't try to force faith on a child. Trying to force a child or teen to worship in a certain way creates much distress, so instead provide freedom of choice and experimentation.
Take your child to many different places of worship, such as a temple, church, gurdwara, cathedral, or mosque so that he/she can actually see them and learn about them.
Introduce him/her to the people who belong to a different religion.
Explain both the positive and negative aspects of all religions.
Purchase or borrow books with teachings from various prophets, and discuss what they mean with kids.
Teach tolerance for each other. Respect the beliefs of others, no matter how much you agree or disagree with them.
Let your child choose a place of worship when they are of age. Be proud that you instilled values of faith and respect in them.
Allow them to ask questions. Answer their questions for as long as you are comfortable. When their curiosity becomes too much for your patience or time, guide them towards books, websites, speakers & movies that you trust as credible sources to answer their questions.
Never answer them something misleading in haste. It may affect their future thoughts.
Encourage them to seek their own answers since religious texts have many interpretations and interpreters. They can be encouraged to reason and relate religious teachings to their daily life.
Accept their stance. If they choose to take time or stay without a choice, allow them. Matters of faith and religion can't be forced. Allow their life incidents and observations to turn their hearts towards a particular religion.
Video
Tips
Let kids ask questions and try your best to provide answers.
Talk about faith openly and let your children know that they are free to talk to you about it.
Warnings
Never speak harshly about other religions. It will give your child a negative view of those religions and push them towards religious intolerance.
Things You'll Need
Various holy books and writings
Access to a library or bookstore
